Welcome to our movement for justice, equality, and dignity; a place where your voice, your values, and your actions come together to create real and lasting change.

Every day, communities around the world face discrimination, exclusion, and silence. But together, we can rewrite that story. Becoming a member of our organization isn’t just a formality; it’s a powerful act of solidarity. It’s choosing to stand with those who have been silenced, to defend the rights that protect us all, and to fight for a future where no one is left behind.

As a member, you become part of a network of committed individuals who believe in justice not as an idea, but as a lived reality; on the ground, in policy, in schools, and on the streets. Your membership helps us advocate with strength, mobilize with courage, and educate with heart.
Join us. Because silence never changed the world; people like you do.

div.p: In a world where injustice often goes unseen or ignored, taking action can feel overwhelming. But real change begins with simple, powerful acts — like adding your name to a cause that matters. By signing our petitions, you're not just supporting an issue; you're standing with communities, amplifying the voices of the unheard, and helping us hold decision-makers accountable.

Each signature we collect is a message: that we demand better, fairer, more compassionate policies and systems. From protecting human rights at borders to defending freedom of expression and ensuring dignity in labor;our petitions are rooted in stories, struggles, and hopes for a more just future.

Your signature is a tool for change. It helps raise awareness, apply public pressure, and push for real reforms. Whether it's stopping child labor, fighting discrimination, or supporting those fleeing violence; you have the power to act.

p.strong: Join the movement. Sign today. Stand for justice, equality, and human dignity — for everyone.

div.p: Join us in defending peaceful protest; a fundamental right under threat in many countries, including ours.

The right to protest is a cornerstone of any functioning democracy. It allows citizens to express dissent, raise awareness, and call for accountability on social, environmental, and political issues. Yet in many countries — even within Europe — this fundamental freedom is increasingly under attack.

Governments are introducing restrictive laws that make it harder for people to gather peacefully. Permits are being denied without cause, spontaneous demonstrations are criminalized, and broad surveillance measures are used to monitor activists and deter participation. These measures often target vulnerable or marginalized communities first; including racialized groups, climate activists, and labor unions; creating a chilling effect on civic participation.

In some countries, protests are violently repressed. Peaceful demonstrators are met with tear gas, rubber bullets, and mass arrests. Protest leaders face intimidation, defamation, or even imprisonment. The media is also threatened or silenced when covering these events, leaving citizens in the dark.

This erosion of protest rights doesn't just silence individuals; it undermines democracy itself. Without the freedom to speak out, societies lose the ability to challenge injustice, hold leaders accountable, and fight for progress. The right to protest must be protected, not punished.

section.class: s_text_image pt80 pb80 o_colored_level o_cc o_cc2

div.p: We urge lawmakers to:

li.p: Uphold the right to peaceful protest
Remove restrictions that target marginalized groups

div.p: Sign this petition to show our leaders that civil society won’t be silenced. Every signature is a signal that peaceful protest is a right; not a crime.

div.p: Help us demand stronger protections and enforcement to stop child labor in the products we use every day

Child labor remains one of the most pressing human rights issues worldwide. Despite global efforts to eradicate it, an estimated 160 million children are still engaged in work that robs them of their childhood, education, and health. Many of these children work in hazardous environments, exposed to dangerous machinery, toxic substances, and extreme conditions that threaten their physical and mental well-being.

What’s more alarming is that child labor is deeply embedded in global supply chains; from cocoa farms in West Africa, to textile factories in South Asia, to mining operations in Latin America. These children often go unseen, hidden behind complex networks of suppliers and subcontractors, making accountability difficult.

Consumers unknowingly support these practices when they purchase products made without transparency or ethical oversight. The lack of enforcement and transparency allows exploitative labor to continue unchecked, perpetuating cycles of poverty and inequality across generations.

Ending child labor is not only a moral imperative; it’s essential for building fair economies and sustainable development. We must demand that companies take responsibility for their entire supply chains and that governments enforce laws protecting children’s rights.

section.class: s_text_image pt80 pb80 o_colored_level o_cc o_cc2

div.p: We call on governments and corporations to:

li.p: Enforce transparency laws on global supply chains
Require companies to disclose labor practices
Penalize those who fail to act responsibly

div.p: Your voice will help push legislation that makes companies accountable. With enough support, we will present this petition to the EU Parliament and national decision-makers as part of our campaign for fair trade and ethical labor.

div.p: Join us in defending peaceful protest; a fundamental right under threat in many countries, including ours.

Across Europe and beyond, refugees and migrants face escalating violence and illegal treatment at national borders; a crisis that remains largely hidden from public view. Instead of offering protection to people fleeing war, persecution, or extreme poverty, many governments are engaging in what’s known as pushbacks: forcibly turning people away at borders without assessing their right to asylum, often through violent and degrading means.

These pushbacks violate both international human rights law and the Geneva Convention, which guarantee the right to seek asylum and humane treatment. Yet border agencies continue to act with impunity;  abandoning migrants at sea, stripping them of their belongings, detaining them in inhumane conditions, or leaving them in remote areas without food or water.

The problem is systemic. Governments are outsourcing border control to countries with poor human rights records, while failing to create safe and legal migration routes. This not only endangers lives, but also normalizes xenophobia and racism under the guise of “security.”

People seeking safety are not criminals; they are families, children, and individuals who have already endured extreme hardship. The continued practice of pushbacks dehumanizes those in need and stains our shared commitment to dignity, compassion, and the rule of law.
